thread.title: 'Mobile' Workers Secure Court Pay Victory

title: 'Mobile' Workers Secure Court Pay Victory
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 10, 2015, 14:53 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 37 mins 'Mobile' Workers Secure Court Pay Victory By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 27 minutes ago View Photo 

A top barrister has told Sky News a ruling by the European Court of Justice could create a "nightmare" for businesses whose workers do not have a fixed office. 
The ruling, made in a case launched in Spain, means that time spent by a 'mobile' worker travelling between homes and the premises of their first and last customers should constitute working time. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) has repercussions for the likes of salespeople and carers. 
The effect could be to not only push up overheads for their employers, as many additional hours will potentially be claimed as work, but mean thousands could claim for lost back pay. 
Employment barrister and chair of the Industrial Law Society, Caspar Glynn, said: "It is in force now and people can bring claims going back for breach of National Minimum wage if, when they have worked out the extra hours seen, if it takes them below (the threshold)." 
The court ruled that its judgement was based on the principles of the European Union's Working Time Directive. 
Commenting on the decision, the executive director of policy and external affairs at the British Chambers of Commerce, Adam Marshall, said: "This ruling underscores the importance of greater national decision-making on employment laws. 
"Once again, a faraway court is taking decisions that could impact business prospects, job creation and economic growth in the UK. 
"Companies of all sizes will be dismayed that Strasbourg is once again intervening in a way that stops EU member-states from running their own labour markets. 
"The ECJ ruling also underscores the importance of securing the UK opt-out from elements of the Working Time Directive."
